trs: It's the twentieth (of September) in the year 2005.
We've come with our aunt{\footnotemark} (Teresinha) to listen to her stories (about our ancestors).
We're here in Carurú Cachoeira.
Sacred burial places/cemeteries
These white ladies have come wanting to hear my stories.' (I was told)
(So) today I'm coming to tell (them).’{\footnotemark}
I'm a descendant of \textit{wãri khutiro biari}.
My name (is) Maria Teresinha Marques.

src: yʉ={\textasciitilde}wabá	so'tóá-í	hí-ra	yʉ’ʉ́-ré	bu'sáná phokó	{\textasciitilde}wabá-tí-há	yʉ’ʉ́
trs: (And){\footnotemark} this is my last (traditional) name, what I'm called is \textit{bu'sana phoko}.
I'm a woman of the \textit{wãri khutiro biari} group.
For me, my father was \textit{wi͂hoa}.’ (I knew him as \textit{wi͂hoa}, his traditional name.)
These (visitors) want to hear (stories).’ (I’m told)

src: {\textasciitilde}a=yóá-kó	yʉ’ʉ́	tí-re	{\textasciitilde}bichá-dáchó-ré	{\textasciitilde}dóá-ro={\textasciitilde}be're	a’rí-{\textasciitilde}da-{\textasciitilde}kida-re yʉ={\textasciitilde}basí-a-poka-re	yʉ=thʉ'ó-tu-a-re	yʉ’ʉ́	dú-ruku{\footnotemark}-ko-ta
trs: So, today with pleasure I'm going to tell them a little of what I know, what I understand.
(Sigh and moment of silence). ‘These are stories about what happened in the origin times.
The origin beings appeared coming upriver here.
Arriving, my ancestors established their houses (their rightful place) here in Matapi.
That place is called \textit{bʉhkakhopa}.
White people say … (they) call that village Matapi.

src: tí-{\textasciitilde}da	a’rí-{\textasciitilde}da	híphiti-{\textasciitilde}da	a’rí-{\textasciitilde}da	ñáhori-a-{\textasciitilde}pho'da wa'í khapea ñáhori-a	hí-a	{\textasciitilde}sa=ba'á-{\textasciitilde}da	wáró
trs: All of these, descendants (children), \textit{wa'i khapea ñahoria}, are our true younger brothers.
(Younger brothers of the) \textit{biari} (Teresinha’s group), the \textit{ñahori} descendants are.’ (they’re saying)
They are the younger second group.’ (they’re saying){\footnotemark}
He (\textit{Ñahori}) had his houses here in \textit{Mukʉ Dʉhpʉri} (and) these ones here (Carurú villagers are) our younger brothers.’ (they’re saying).

trs: In those olden times, the custom was to marry two wives, two or even three.

src: {\textasciitilde}dabó-tí	a’rí	{\textasciitilde}ó-ré	matapí	wʉ'ʉ́-kho'to-ri	tí-ró bʉkʉ́-ró	{\textasciitilde}bari={\textasciitilde}yʉchʉ́	diánúmíá.yáíró
trs: The old one, our grandfather (ancestor) \textit{Dianumia Yairo}, was married (and) he had houses there in Matapi.’ (they’re saying)
There were lots of people living there.
So (they’re saying) that \textit{Ñahori} lived just there (in \textit{Mukʉ Dʉhpʉri} and said to) \textit{Yuhpi Diani}:
“I'm going to get women, my sisters-in-law.”
When (\textit{Ñahori}) said that, (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) asked:
“Bring one more wife for me too,” (he asked to \textit{Ñahori}, the father) of all these \textit{Ñahoria} descendants here.
I guess the rascal (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) really liked/needed (women), hum … hum.’ [Teresinha chuckles]

trs: So, he (\textit{Ñahori}) went to get them, brought (them) back, and went off to the gardens over there (in \textit{Mukʉ Dʉhpʉri}).

trs: \textit{Mukʉ Dʉhpʉri} is the rightful place of these \textit{ñahoria}.
Their place is on the other side of the river, and that place is still theirs.

trs: If they were to come back there, no one could ask \textit{Ñahori}’s descendants “Why do you come (what are you doing) here?”
No one could say that.
It's his (\textit{Ñahori}’s) origin site.
So, (\textit{Ñahori} and the woman) came up (towards \textit{Yuhpi Diani}).

src: a’rí-kó-ró	yʉ’ʉ́-ré	{\textasciitilde}dúbí-á	{\textasciitilde}dá yʉ’ʉ́	dutí-ri-ko-ro	tí-re	a’rí-kó-ró	{\textasciitilde}dí-a	tí-ró
trs: “This woman's for me, the one I asked you to get,” he (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) said.

src: a’rí-ro	ñáhórí	hi-éra-re sóró-pʉ́	diáni	yá-kó-ró	hí-ra	{\textasciitilde}dí-a
trs: \textit{Ñahori} (speaking): “Not so, this one is promised to \textit{Diani},” he said.
“Not so! I ordered (her),” (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) said.
“I ordered (her). She's mine!” (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) said.
“No (she's) not,” (\textit{Ñahori}) said.
That said, (she) went to the garden (and) returning, was grabbed.
“(You) stay with me,” said (\textit{Diani}).
“(She) isn’t (yours). You want (her but) I'll get another one for you,” (said \textit{Ñahori}).
“No,” said (\textit{Diani}).
Saying that, (\textit{Diani}) grabbed her.
Poor thing! The old gal was all alone.

src: {\textasciitilde}sʉ́	to={\textasciitilde}badʉ́-ro-re	yabá-re	khá-{\textasciitilde}dʉ́kó-ré	hí-pha-to	tí-ró yuhpi.diani
trs: (\textit{Ñahori}) went there to her intended husband in \textit{Kha Nʉhko} (Hawk Island), where \textit{Yuhpi Diani} lived (and said):
“Your (intended) wife's gone, your older brother’s people captured her,” said (\textit{Ñahori}).
Saying that to his servants,{\footnotemark} the next day two of them went (to check).

src: tí-kó-ró	kówa-ro	bu'á-ta-ri-ko-ro-re	pharí-taro-pʉ tí-kó-ró-ré	{\textasciitilde}ya'á-a	tí-{\textasciitilde}da
trs: When the woman came down to fetch water from the pond, they grabbed her.
She resisted them: “Let me go! I'm reserved for one from the higher clan,” she said.
“Your (true) husband is calling you right now,” said (the servants, to no avail).
[(She) didn't want (to go)!]’{\footnotemark}
(She) didn't want (to go), resisted (and) escaped (their) embrace.
His (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s) servants, [the future \textit{Ñahoria}] were just this tall.
There were two little guys.
They ran up (to tell \textit{Yuhpi Diani}):
“It’s too late, your wife's already taken.”
Those servants (and) he (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) himself came back with arrows and started shooting.
[We're grandchildren (descendants) of grandparents (ancestors) who used arrows.]
(\textit{Diani}'s people) shot (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s servant) right here in the stomach.
They came crawling back.
(They) found wild bananas (and) chopped (them to extract the liquid) to make a cure for him (the wounded guy).
(They) took (him) right up to their leader\textit{Yuhpi Diani}.
“You made this happen to us,” they said.
“Now we're going to kill you!” (they) said.
“No you won't, my servants. Don’t do that to me.”
“I'm your leader. I myself can resolve things,” he (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) said.
Saying that, the servants started making arrows (preparing for war).
[He (\textit{Yuhpi Diani} and) the ones who would become (your) grandfathers.]’\\
Our younger brother, \textit{Ñahori}, lived alone with his wives, two women …

src: to={\textasciitilde}pho'dá-{\textasciitilde}ka	phʉá-ro-{\textasciitilde}ka	to=phayó-a	phʉá-ro-{\textasciitilde}ka seis{\footnotemark}=ta  		hí-a	tí-{\textasciitilde}da	{\textasciitilde}ó-ré	múkʉ.dʉhpʉri-re
trs: two children and two servants, they were exactly six here in \textit{Mukʉ Dʉhpʉri}.
Three weeks later, the warrier (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) came upstream with his servants, to the sound of \textit{piriaka} flutes.

src: tí	phá-pʉ́-ré	yá-ró-{\textasciitilde}ká	tí-{\textasciitilde}da	{\textasciitilde}kha'bá-{\textasciitilde}waha-éra	hí-{\textasciitilde}bare-bʉ	tutu...tutu...tutuuuuu
trs: In those times, it wasn't the custom to make war silently (but to play flutes) \textit{tutu ... tutu ... tutuuuuu} ...

trs: They arrived here in \textit{Wãhsipiria Nʉ̃hko} (island, and) the warriors came up the path until they arrived (at \textit{Ñahori}'s house).

src: tí-ró	bi'á-sã'a-{\textasciitilde}ba-to	tí-ró khatá-ró-sópáká-í	duhí-a	tí-ró	bʉkʉ́-ro
trs: He (\textit{Ñahori}) barred (the entrance, in vain, and), the old guy sat next to the opening to the flatbread oven.

src: ñáhórí	to={\textasciitilde}wa'básítía={\textasciitilde}be're{\footnotemark}-ta a’rí	wʉhʉ́{\textasciitilde}dítí	a’rí	{\textasciitilde}dóá-ró	híphiti-ro	to=doká-a={\textasciitilde}be're
trs: \textit{Ñahori} with all his adornments, the ceremonial perfume (and) all of his weapons.
They (\textit{Yuhpi Diani} and warriors) arrived. (They) were coming up in a line.
[What? um, um ... Embaúba tree, [is that what it's called?]
They had a lot of strips of molongó wood that they had sharpened …
[That (I suppose) were like a shield for them.]
“(They're) coming, master!” (\textit{Ñahori}'s servants) said.
(\textit{Ñahori} 's) two poor servants taunted them: “\textit{To ... to ... tooooooo}, hated sons of our enemy!"
“We're going to mow you down!” the poor terrified ones yelled.
(But) they (\textit{Ñahori}'s servants) were overwhelmed, there were too many of the others.
Those poor guys who just had spears, were terrified, \textit{Ñahori}'s servants ...’\\
they sat up there waiting with their shields.
Shooting but unable to resist, (the servants) cried (in vain): “There are too many of them, master. Run away!”
“I'm not going! I'm going to defeat them all!” he (\textit{Ñahori}) said.
“No! I myself can (defeat them),” (\textit{Ñahori} ) said.
Saying that, Ñahori ordered his wives: “Take the children away!” he said.’\\
“Yes!” (they) said. They got the children (and) put them in (their basket with) jaguar-teeth necklaces (and other sacred objects).
[His wives’ two children.]
“We can't resist anymore! You take over, master. We love you,” (\textit{Ñahori}’s servants) said.
He (\textit{Ñahori}) himself came out crouching down (and) shooting arrows.

src: tíá́-ta	quátro-ta-ri	tí-ró-ré	{\textasciitilde}ó	wáró-i	bʉé-thu'sʉ-a	tí-{\textasciitilde}da chʉʉʉ! tʉ...tʉ...tʉʉʉʉʉʉʉʉʉ	phuhu!
trs: After three (or) four rounds, an arrow hit him (\textit{Ñahori}). \textit{Chʉʉʉ! tʉ ... tʉ ... tʉʉʉʉ! phuhu!}’ (sounds of arrows flying, striking \textit{Ñahori} and his falling down.)
He collapsed trembling right next to the oven.
He fell over.
After his fall{\footnotemark} (\textit{Diani}'s warriors cried): “You deserved it, evil enemy!”
(They) shouted: “\textit{Hʉʉʉʉ!} ... We got (killed) him!” (and then) rolled his body over.
(They) burned down all the houses.
So, the others (from Matapi) were watching the confusion from afar.
[Was that when it was?]
[Was at this time or not when (the women in Matapi) saw the smoke rising?]
So (they commented to) their husbands ... [we women are such gossips! (story-tellers)]
“Look there! Have those people killed our \textit{Ñahori}?” (they speculated).
“The smoke from the houses has been rising for a long time!” (they) said.
“Oh no! Is it true?” (they wondered) looking from afar.
“Let's go see!”

src: tí-phá-ré	{\textasciitilde}ba'á-ri	hí-ati-ri	hí-{\textasciitilde}bare-bʉ tá-átí	phá-ati	pʉ́	a’rí	múkʉ.dʉhpʉri-pʉ
trs: [In those days it seems there were already paths coming all the way to \textit{Mukʉ Dʉhpʉri} (\textit{Ñahori}’s place).]
Poor folks! When they got there, the houses were already collapsing ... \textit{Karaa!}’ (sound of houses falling down)
“\textit{Ñahori} ... \textit{Ñahori} children ... (they've) killed all of you together!” the \textit{Biari} cried.
They (the ones who had escaped) didn't answer, fearful of being slaughtered.
“(They're) coming back to kill us!” (they) thought.
Later, (the \textit{Biari}) cried out, “Where have you gone, \textit{Ñahori} children?”
“Could they have killed all of you?”
[If \textit{Yuhpi Diani} had killed off the little ones, there wouldn't be all these \textit{Ñahoria}.]’ (referring to the audience)
There were two little boys.
When (the \textit{Biari}) were about to give up looking, (the boys) answered: “\textit{ʉʉʉʉʉʉ}.” (We’re here!)
“Come on out! We're looking for you,” (the \textit{Biari}) cried.
When the poor little ones and \textit{Ñahori}'s wives arrived, (they asked) them: “What happened to you?”
“(They) all came to kill our husband,” (the women) said.
“It was us, we took the little ones away.”
“Good thing!” (the \textit{Biari}) answered.
“We will care for the two little ones (and) the jaguar-teeth basket (and other sacred objects),” his older brothers (the \textit{Biari}) said.
Taking the little ones (they) went looking around where the fire was going out, (and saw) the poor guy fallen at the edge of the oven, his big skull lying on the ground.
It was \textit{Ñahori} lying there all burned up.
They became furious.
“Very well, (they've) done this to our younger brother (killed him),” (the \textit{Biari}) said.
They returned home.
Their father, \textit{Dianumia (Yairo)}, our grandfather was there.
“Well, what happened, sons?” (\textit{Dianumia Yairo} asked).
“Over there they burned our younger brother. (They) killed (him)!” (they) said.
“Enough, my sons, it's over, it was his own fault.”
“No, we won’t leave it at that, father. We're still going to avenge him.”
“How could he just disappear without being avenged?” (they) added that too.
[Yes, you men sometimes like to say things like that.]

imt: 1\textsc{pl.excl} kill-\textsc{compl-sw.ref}	1\textsc{pl.excl.poss}=younger.brother\textsc{-obj}	like.this	do\textsc{-nmlz}	\textsc{cop-obj} say-\textsc{assert.ipfv}	\textsc{alt}\textsc{-nmlz.sg}	speak-stand	strong\textsc{-nmlz-sg}	hear-know\textsc{-nmlz-sg}
src: {\textasciitilde}sá {\textasciitilde}wahá-{\textasciitilde}ha-chʉ	{\textasciitilde}sa=ba'ʉ́-re	{\textasciitilde}óse	yóá-rí	hí-re {\textasciitilde}dí-ka	pá-író	dú-rúkú	tuá-ri-ro	thʉ'ó-{\textasciitilde}basi-ri-ro
trs: [When one of us is killed, (you) tell our brother to do that (fight, seek revenge), (or) some other one who talks big, is a braggart.]
“Well then, I warned (you, in vain), I told (you) otherwise, (but) so be it.”’ (\textit{Dianumia Yairo} speaking)
“You take care of it yourselves, my sons.”
“(I’m) warning you like this, (you) of this next (younger) generation, (but you) aren't listening.”
Saying that angrily, (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) prepared adornments.

imt: \textsc{anph-sg}	ancestor\textsc{-sg}	tobacco-\textsc{clf:}cylindrical	two-\textsc{clf:}cylindrical	good\textsc{-sg}	bad\textsc{-nmlz-sg}	blow-penetrate-\textsc{assert.pfv}
trs: The old guy made two cigars, blowing smoke on them (to bless, or imbue them with violence for success in battle).
They (the \textit{Biari}), as soon as he said that, set straight away to preparing their weapons.

src: {\textasciitilde}so'ó	{\textasciitilde}sa={\textasciitilde}bí-pʉ́	hí-ro-re	bʉé-a-{\textasciitilde}khadʉ	péri	hí-ati-{\textasciitilde}bare bʉé-a	bʉé-a-{\textasciitilde}khadʉ	{\textasciitilde}ó-{\textasciitilde}báhá-dótó-rí	wáró
trs: [There, in the place we live now (Matapi), there used to be a lot of arrow-cane, arrows, arrow-cane, big bundles this tall.]
(Each warrier) made six good bundles (of arrows).
“Tell our younger brother \textit{Yuhpi Diani} to be expecting us,” they sent off a message.
[(But) if it were you, better to attack without letting them know!]’ (Teresinha jokes with Joselito)

imt: bad\textsc{-nmlz.pl}	go.downriver-come	\textsc{deic.prox-emph}	path\textsc{-loc}	come-\textsc{assert.pfv} until	wãhsipiria	pond\textsc{-loc}.vis
trs: The warriors came down right over here, on the river, coming right up to the \textit{Wãhsipiria} pond (river port).
Their canoes were huge bark canoes.
[How did the warriors make those bark canoes?]
Right down here (they) came.
They went (through the rapids), dragging the canoes (on the rocks) over here.’{\footnotemark}
The warriors came down to the constant sound of \textit{phiriaka} flutes: \textit{pu ... pu ... puuuuuuu!}
(\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s men) were already there ready waiting, (and) when (the \textit{Biari}) landed, they starting right in firing arrows at them.
They too (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s men) returned fire, (but the \textit{Biari}) weren’t hit.
Poor guys, his (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s) servants …
(While) from the opposite side the others (\textit{Biari}) continued on (shooting).
Already exhausted, after their (the \textit{Biari}’s) last (arrow) arrived, (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s servants) threw rocks (at the \textit{Biari}).
There, it's said (that), in the old times, there in \textit{Khã Nʉhko} …
in the end, (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s men) dug trenches, it seems that's just how it was.
[“That why it's an island (that has) trenches with their spilled blood, my daughter,” (my father said).{\footnotemark}]

imt: maybe	old-times	end\textsc{-loc-obj}	do/bring.together-kill	disappear\textsc{-pl-predict}	\textsc{dem.prox}	island\textsc{-obj}
trs: [“Maybe, in the future they're all going to kill each other and disappear from the island.”]
[My dad (and) my late grandfather used to say that.]
[My father told (me), used to tell (me).]

src: {\textasciitilde}a=tó	dií-{\textasciitilde}khoa-ro	hí-ro	{\textasciitilde}dí-yu'ka{\footnotemark}	tó {\textasciitilde}a=hí-a	tí-{\textasciitilde}da	{\textasciitilde}kha'báchʉ-a	phayʉ́	{\textasciitilde}dí-ka	tó-re
trs: [So they say it's a place that has spilled bood. That's why they're always fighting there.]
[They're ones who never received the (anti-)war blessing, to make them sweet (calm, non-violent).]
[It will always be an unblessed island, a violent island.]
[So everyone is violent.]
So, (they, \textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s servants) gave up.
[Where are those ‘potato’ rapids?{\footnotemark} I wonder where those rapids are.]
(Joselito responds) ‘[The Inambú (hawk) headwaters are over there.]
“Hello?” (\textit{Diani}'s warriors, the \textit{Biari}) called out (in vain), but poor guys, there was no one.
Looking all over (the island): “Where have they gone?” (they) wondered.
Three days passed (and) the next night (\textit{Dianumia Yairo} and his warriors from Matapi) came downriver.
Poor guys (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s servants). (The \textit{Biari}) could hear from afar the sound of chopping: \textit{Tho! Tho! Tho!}
The other frightened ones (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}’s servants) were finishing up (the construction) of a barricade.
They finished the barricade, where they could be up high (on a platform).
It was called then \textit{khakhasario}, it was a “hawk's nest” that they built.
“He's at fault, your brother wouldn't listen.”
“(But) there are two \textit{Ñahori} children, they will multiply (reproduce),” (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) said (in vain, still trying to convince them).
“We refuse! We refuse! We refuse! We absolutely refuse!” (they) insisted.
“All right” (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) said.

imt: hear\textsc{-pl}	night	\textsc{q-quant.c-nmlz.pl}	come\textsc{-pl}	\textsc{prog-assert.pfv}	bad\textsc{-nmlz.pl} four or six	\textsc{cop-pl-q.pfv}	\textsc{anph}
src: thʉ'ó-a	{\textasciitilde}yabí	{\textasciitilde}do'ó-pe-{\textasciitilde}ida	tá-a	{\textasciitilde}dí-a	{\textasciitilde}yá-{\textasciitilde}ida quatro ou seis	hí-a-ri	tí({\textasciitilde}da)
trs: Hearing (the sounds from the barracade), at night … [how many warriors were there – four or six of them maybe?]
(They) went right up to the barricade.
They (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s servants) were making a good barricade, like this with no open spaces (to get through).
\textit{Dianumia Yairo} (and his men) quickly transformed into worms.
[That's the way it was in ancient times, (they) transformed (and) all of them went (into the ground).]
When they came out right beside (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s) servants, they cried out:
“Come down, master!”
“You (decided) ‘I’m going to start (this war)’, it's your fault this is happening to us!”
“You come too, to help with our work,” (the servants) said.
“All right,” said (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}).
(The servants) sent up a curse on him (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}).
“All right,” he said (and they) lit up a torch (to light the way) for him.
With the light, the poor terrified guy (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) started down ...
Coming way down! “You [how was it?] you yourself cut the central beam (of the barricade),” (the servants) said.
“OK” (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) said (and) came sliding down.
With his torch burning, he grabbed his machete (and) when he started to chop (the beam), the warriors (\textit{Biari}) captured him.
“No! Servants, the warriors have captured me!”
“Quickly, you get your arrows too!” (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}) cried.
(But) in the dark, they just ran around like this looking for (things).
(They) threw him down on the ground, holding him here.

src: tí	to	a’rí	{\textasciitilde}tayó=ba'ro	tó-pʉ-ta	du'ú-páyó-á	to=dʉsó-re
trs: On a beam just like this one here, they (\textit{Dian}i's warriors) left his (\textit{Yuhpi Diani}'s) leg.
[But those guys then had axes too — what were they?]
[\textit{Bookhoma}! Yes ... do you suppose to them that (kind of) axe{\footnotemark} was sharp?]
[(For) us (that old kind) aren't axes, (just) rocks, they were rocks.]
(Joselito) ‘[Yes.]

src: dʉté-tá-dóká	doká-payo-a	té	to	ka'á-pʉ́ khá-khásá-ríó	ti={\textasciitilde}dí-ro-pʉ
trs: (They) chopped off (his leg and) threw it all the way up near that (thing) they call the hawk's nest platform.
“Enemy, evil son, (we got) him for what he himself did to our brother!”
“Guilty one! Murderer! You evil bastard!”

imt: embark.in.canoe	until	go.upriver-\textsc{assert.pfv}	until	\textsc{deic.prox-loc}	go.uphill-arrive.\textsc{trns}	arrive.\textsc{trns}-\textsc{assert.pfv}
trs: (They) got into their canoes (and) came upriver here, went up (the hill and) arrived home.
(Their father \textit{Dianumia Yairo} asked): “Were you successful, sons?”
“We were, father,” (\textit{Diani}) responded.
“We did it, (killed) the one responsible for the evil he did to our relative,” (\textit{Diani}) said.
“Those evil ones who did that to our brother.”
“He couldn't expect anything good to happen,” (\textit{Diani}) said.
“Very well, you, my children who come after me (of the next generation) just won't listen/obey,” (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) said.
“Just like now, you ignore (me, you aren't ones who listen),” said (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}).
“So be it,” he said (and) took back his war adornments (and) his blessing for courage.
Blowing smoke on them, they became the way they are now (peaceful), no longer in that violent state.

imt: so=do	tomorrow\textsc{-dim}	lighten-go\textsc{-sg-loc.vis}	manioc	get-\textsc{imp.3} 2\textsc{pl.poss}=wife\textsc{-pl.f}	say-\textsc{assert.pfv}
trs: “So, the day after tomorrow, send your wives to get manioc,” he ordered.

src: tí-{\textasciitilde}da	basá-bátóá-ró	tá-ro	tí-{\textasciitilde}da	khʉ́-{\textasciitilde}da	da'ré
trs: For the last ceremony (celebrating their victory in war), they got manioc (and) prepared (caxiri).'{\footnotemark}
[On those celebration days, they chanted ceremonial dances (like) the flatbread dance.]
[These are traditional (origin) dances: flatbread dance, lizard dance — what else? — fruit dance, peace (holding hands) dance.]
They performed all the dances for two days (and then \textit{Dianumia Yairo} said):
“I'm going away now.” [To the place he still is sitting.]

imt: \textsc{neg}	\textsc{dem.prox}	halluc.powder	jaguar-eat\textsc{-pl}-halluc.powder	kidnap-people-halluc.powder summer-halluc.powder	hungry	big\textsc{-nmlz}	\textsc{neg}	2\textsc{pl-obj}	leave/place\textsc{-neg.irr}	say-\textsc{assert.pfv}
trs: “Not my hallucinogenic powder, nor the one that can transform you into jaguars to eat people, nor the one to kidnap people (to become invisible), nor the one that brings on summer, nor will I leave the one that causes hunger,” (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) said.
“All of these things here I'm taking away,” (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) said.
“(Because) you will always just do what you want.”

imt: 1\textsc{pl.incl}	angry-man/person\textsc{-pl}	halluc.powder	sniff	1\textsc{pl.incl-obj}	offend\textsc{-sg-obj}	\textsc{ontp:}hurting jaguar-eat	finish-\textsc{assert.ipfv-emph}
trs: [When we get angry, we sniff powder to turn into a jaguar and devour (fight with, or kill) the one who has offended us.]
[That's how our powder used to be, Kotiria powder.]
[But people weren't supposed to keep sniffing it all the time.]
[It was just the kind for face-painting (which already has an effect).]
The whole basket (with all the materials), (he) had that basket.
(He) took up his staff (and) put his shield on his arm.
His dog went up ahead, up there.
[They were the house jaguars (guards).]
[They're the ones (jaguars) that nowadays are a danger to us, there where we live (in Matapi).]
He went way off (to the place he had selected), and his wife was following behind.
It was our place up there where it thunders, the sacred place (called) \textit{Dʉrʉwero}.’{\footnotemark}
There she stomped on the ground like this: \textit{Thʉ! Thʉ! Thʉ!}' (making a thundering sound)
“What's that?” she wondered (but \textit{Dianumia Yairo}) didn't even turn around.

imt: \textsc{q:}how	nephew	1\textsc{pl.incl.poss}=disappear-\textsc{nmlz.loc/evnt}	\textsc{emph-obj}	far\textsc{-sg-emph} \textsc{cop-nmlz}	\textsc{cop-clf:}gen-\textsc{nmlz.loc/evnt}	\textsc{anph-sg}	ancestor\textsc{-sg} \textsc{neg}	turn.around	look\textsc{-neg-assert.pfv}	go-go-\textsc{assert.pfv}
src: do'sé	{\textasciitilde}chóa	{\textasciitilde}bari=butí-to	waro-re	yoá-ro-ta {\textasciitilde}dí-ri	hí-re-to	tí-ró	bʉkʉ́-ro {\textasciitilde}dé	{\textasciitilde}baháré	{\textasciitilde}yʉ-éra-a 	wa'á-wa'a-a
trs: (addressing Joselito) ‘[Because, nephew, (for him) it was just as it will be for us in the future (our disappearance, death, burial) — the old ancestor ... didn't even look back, off he went.]
Until he (got to the place) now called \textit{Khãre Khu’tu} (and) made himself comfortable.
He had his two servants.
(They) carried his bench, his shaman staff (and) shield.

src: a’ría-(bʉ')se	to=dié-ro	ba'á-ro-(bʉ')se	to=dié-ro	sié-(bʉ')sé-{\textasciitilde}yʉ́-dóká	yoá-a
trs: Here (in front was) his dog/jaguar and behind his (other) dog/jaguar (and he sat) looking off straight ahead into the distance.
(He) sat for two days (and) on the third day, it was already up to here (his body entering into the ground).
“Come back in four, five (days), a week,” (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) said.
“I, your father, will truly be going (to another world), right in the middle of the night.”
“I'll be going in (to the ground and) there will be a thunderous sound for me (and) you, my children will hear,” (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) said.

src: hái	{\textasciitilde}dí-a	dé	tó-puro	to={\textasciitilde}dí-rí-ba'ro	bisí-a	tʉʉʉʉʉ
trs: “All right,” (they) answered (and) poor guy ... just at the time he indicated, there was a sound: \textit{Thʉʉʉʉʉ} ...' (thunder)
“Poor guy! Our father's gone,” (they) said.
“Go there and see,” (they) said. (But) there was nothing there.
Because (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) had disappeared into (the ground, alive).

imt: so=do-\textsc{sg-nmlz.loc/evnt}	women	cause\textsc{-nmlz}	cause\textsc{-nmlz}	say-\textsc{assert.pfv}	\textsc{def-obj} cause-proper.place	\textsc{cop-spec-nmlz.loc/evnt}
trs: That's why, because of women, (that cemetery) is called \textit{Bu'i Kho’to} (place of guilt/problem), it seems so.

imt: women	cause\textsc{-nmlz}	like.this	do	angry	3\textsc{sg.poss}=\textsc{mov.}inside-remain\textsc{-nmlz-sg} \textsc{anph}-cemetery	people	\textsc{poss-nmlz}-cemetery
trs: It was because of women that he angrily went into that ground, the cemetery for our own bodies.

imt: cause-proper.place	\textsc{cop-assert.pfv}	\textsc{def=contr-obj-emph}	1\textsc{pl.excl-contr}	find\textsc{-neg-attrib} \textsc{q:}how	do	cause-proper.place	say\textsc{-pl}\textsc{-nmlz}	say	wonder-\textsc{vis.pfv.}1
src: bu'í-kho'to	hí-a	tó=se'e-re-ta	{\textasciitilde}sá-se'e	boka-éra-ti do'sé	yoá	bu'í-kho'to	{\textasciitilde}dí-á-rí	{\textasciitilde}dí	{\textasciitilde}wakú-i
trs: (Joselito speaking) ‘[(Yes) it's \textit{Bu'i Kho'to}. So that's it ... we didn't know why (people) called it that …
(Teresinha responding) ‘[That's the way my father used to tell it.]
[Like I said, if I were a man, I would have asked (and) understood more.{\footnotemark}]
[(But) I unfortunately wasn’t paying enough attention to what little he said, you know?’]
“That's what happened, daughter,” (father) used to say.
“So that all the (Kotiria) groups would have (a place) to be buried.”

imt: \textsc{dem.prox-pl}	small.stone\textsc{-pl}	shiny-\textsc{clf:}round	small.stone\textsc{-pl}	green/blue-\textsc{clf:}round small.stone\textsc{-pl}	black-\textsc{clf:}round	small.stone\textsc{-pl}	white-\textsc{clf:}round	lie\textsc{-sg-predict}	say-\textsc{assert.pfv}
trs: “There will be the place of Shiny Stones, the place of Green Stones, the place of Black Stones (and) the place of White Stones,” (father) said.
(And) now we're divided into groups, like a flatbread cut into fourths.
So, the entrance (first part) is for Shiny Stone burials, our grounds (for the highest clan).

imt: so=\textsc{cop-sg}	people-older.brother\textsc{-sg}	die-\textsc{nmlz.loc/evnt}	before	night-middle/center	sound-\textsc{alt}-do.moving-\textsc{nmlz.loc/evnt}	get\textsc{-nmlz}-house
trs: That's why, before an older brother dies, in the middle of the night, a loud noise comes from the house/cemetery (where the person will be) taken.
\textit{Thʉʉʉʉ!} (or) sometimes \textit{Khaaaa!} is always the sound.

src: a’rí-a-se	khʉ́-ré	{\textasciitilde}átá	{\textasciitilde}bʉsá	yá-khu'tu	a’rí-a-se {\textasciitilde}dá-rí	ye'sé-ria	ñáhórí	yá-ró	ya'sá-ria
trs: It's the same in other places, your place, White Stones (for the \textit{Diani} and) for the \textit{Ñahori}, Green Stones.
Over there in Black Stones is where \textit{Ñahori} children lie.
“So, it's like a flatbread divided in fourths,” (my father) used to say.

src: {\textasciitilde}basá-pé	tí-{\textasciitilde}da	yabá-{\textasciitilde}ida	puertu paloma,	yabá-ro	hí-hari
trs: Everyone, those ones from Puerto Paloma (the last Kotiria village) — how’s it called?

src: pá-{\textasciitilde}ida	{\textasciitilde}ʉrí-{\textasciitilde}da-pʉ-re	{\textasciitilde}dá-{\textasciitilde}bʉha	tí-{\textasciitilde}ba'a	bʉkʉ́-{\textasciitilde}ba'a	hí-ro {\textasciitilde}dí-{\textasciitilde}ba-{\textasciitilde}da-ro	to=bu'ía-re	tí-{\textasciitilde}ba'a
trs: They carried other rotting bodies up that old path that's always been there, the path from the \textit{Bu'ia} stream (leading to the cemetery).
It's the same path we always use to go back and forth (to our gardens).
They brought the poor decomposing bodies (on that path) to \textit{Khãre Kho’to}.

imt: \textsc{anph-pl}	cry-go	cry-go	come-\textsc{vis.ipfv.}2/3 1\textsc{pl.excl.poss}=grandfather	2\textsc{sg}	want-\textsc{vis.ipfv.}2/3	people\textsc{-obj}	get\textsc{-pl}	1\textsc{pl.excl.poss}=love\textsc{-nmlz.pl-obj}
trs: They come weeping, weeping (saying): “You, our grandfather, want it, so we give you the body of the ones we love.”

imt: now\textsc{-loc-obj}	take.care-\textsc{imp}	\textsc{emph}	say	many	say-\textsc{add}	do.together-\textsc{sw.ref}	cry-\textsc{assert.pfv}
trs: “Now take good care (of this body),” (they said), and said many other things, weeping together.
But (they) would only go painted, and only the women of that clan (family of that specific community) could go along.
A woman who wasn’t part of the clan had to return before getting to the cemetery.

imt: arrive\textsc{.cis}	return-arrive\textsc{.cis}	medicine	vomit-\textsc{mov.}through	bathe-\textsc{mov.}through	throw-\textsc{dist}	look.for-eat
trs: Arriving home, (they cleansed themselves with) vomit medicine, bathed to throw off (the effect of the burial), then had something to eat ...
“This is how it's (always) done,” my late father used to tell (me) about the cemetery.
Because our old ancestor (\textit{Dianumia Yairo}) who went up there is still sitting there (still exists, lives there).
That body is there.

src: tí-ró	yaríá-rí-ró	hi-éra-re	hí-{\textasciitilde}bare-ro	tí-ró	a’rí	phákʉ-i	tí-ró
trs: He isn't dead, he's there (alive), his body.
[Sometimes I ask myself: “Could he be God?”]
He's the one who has/controls time.
That's what my late father told (me) about this cemetery, about how things were back then.
